proposed model.from sentence:
Speech naturalness
The proposed model achieved about 4.0 MOS in all datasets , with the VCTK model obtaining a MOS about 0.2 points higher than the LibriSpeech model when evaluated on seen speakers .

audio generated.from sentence: Most importantly , the audio generated by our model for unseen speakers is deemed to be at least as natural as that generated for seen speakers .

MOS on unseen speakers.from sentence: Surprisingly , the MOS on unseen speakers is higher than that of seen speakers , by as much as 0.2 points on LibriSpeech .

scores for.from sentence:
Speaker similarity
The scores for the VCTK model tend to be higher than those for LibriSpeech , reflecting the cleaner nature of the dataset .

baseline.uses: embedding lookup table for speaker conditioning

seen speakers on VCTK.from sentence: For seen speakers on VCTK , the proposed model performs about as well as the baseline which uses an embedding lookup table for speaker conditioning .

trained on.from sentence:
Speaker verification
As shown in , as long as the synthesizer was trained on a sufficiently large set of speakers , i.e. on LibriSpeech , the synthesized speech is typically most similar to the ground truth voices .

On.from sentence: On this 20 voice discrimination task we obtain an EER of 2.86 % , demonstrating that , while the synthetic speech tends to be close to the target speaker ( cosine similarity > 0.6 , and as in ) , it is nearly always even closer to other synthetic utterances for the same speaker ( similarity > 0.7 ) .

PCA visualization.from sentence:
Speaker embedding space
The PCA visualization ( left ) shows that synthesized utterances tend to lie very close to real speech from the same speaker in the embedding space .

where.from sentence: However , synthetic utterances are still easily distinguishable from the real human speech as demonstrated by the t - SNE visualization ( right ) where utterances from each synthetic speaker form a distinct cluster adjacent to a cluster of real utterances from the corresponding speaker .

Number of speaker encoder training speak.from sentence:
Number of speaker encoder training speakers
As the number of training speakers increases , both naturalness and similarity improve significantly .

conditioning.from sentence:
Fictitious speakers
Bypassing the speaker encoder network and conditioning the synthesizer on random points in the speaker embedding space results in speech from fictitious speakers which are not present in the train or test sets of either the synthesizer or the speaker encoder .
